page.title: 12Local History on Horse-Eye
page.content: Horse-Eye Level and Whelpley Level have their own little bit of local history. They derive their names from the ancient word eye meaning isolated small island. It is thought that this dates from the time when the area was mainly under the sea. Local Historians consider it probable that this area was that used by the invading fleet of William of Normandy in 1066. Other facts of history include the Drove Road. This road starts on Horse-Eye Level, travels across the marsh to what is now known as Marshfoot Lane, Hailsham to the cattle market there. The cattle were driven in herds along this route, hence the name Drove Road. It is also interesting to note the road runs parallel with Horse-Eye River & White Dyke & meets with Hurst Haven on the marsh.
